Spicy Shrimp Pilaf Recipe | Bon Appétit




Skip to main contentOpen Navigation MenuMenuStory SavedTo revisit this article, visit My Profile, then View saved stories.Close AlertCloseStory SavedTo revisit this article, select My Account, then View saved storiesClose AlertCloseSign InSearchRecipesCookingCultureShoppingRestaurantsBA MarketVideosPodcastMerch ShoprecipesApril 2021 IssueSpicy Shrimp PilafBy Andy BaraghaniMarch 16, 20214.3(42)Read ReviewsTriangleEmailPinterestPrintPhotograph by Laura Murray, food styling by Rebecca Jurkevich, prop styling by Sophie StrangioEmailPinterestPrintEmailPinterestPrintWhen preparing a pilaf we normally try to cook meat or fish (when using it) along with the rice to allow flavors to mingle. In this case the shrimp cook so quickly that it’s better to pan-fry them separately and combine with the rice at the very end. Senior food editor Andy Baraghani recommends using the highest quality basmati rice you can find (Andy loves extra long sella basmati rice from Mihan) for a perfectly fluffy and fragrant pilaf.Ingredients4 Servings¼cup plus 2 Tbsp. ghee or vegetable oil2medium red onions, thinly sliced1½tsp. Diamond Crystal or 1 tsp. Morton kosher salt, plus more4whole dried chiles de árbol or 1 tsp. crushed red pepper flakes2Tbsp. double-concentrated tomato paste4tsp. ground coriander, divided2tsp. freshly ground black pepper, divided1tsp. ground turmeric, divided1½cups basmati rice, rinsed until water runs clear1lb. large shrimp, peeled, deveined3garlic cloves, finely grated2tsp. finely grated ginger½cup coarsely chopped cilantro, dill, or mintLime wedges (for serving)PreparationStep 1Melt ¼ cup ghee in a medium pot over medium heat. Add onions, season with salt, and cook, stirring occasionally, until deeply golden brown and starting to look lacy (this will take some time!), 15–20 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer half of the onions to a plate and set aside for serving.Step 2Add chiles de árbol, tomato paste, 2 tsp. coriander, 1 tsp. pepper, and ½ tsp. turmeric to onions still in pot. Cook, stirring often, until tomato paste darkens slightly, about 3 minutes. Add rice and cook, stirring, until each grain is well coated, about 30 seconds. Add 1½ tsp. salt, pour in 2¼ cups water, and give mixture a stir to prevent any grains from sticking to bottom of pot. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low and cover pot. Let rice cook until water is completely absorbed and rice is tender, 16–18 minutes. Remove pot from heat and let rice sit (still covered) 15 minutes.Step 3While the rice is resting, toss shrimp with garlic, ginger, remaining 2 tsp. coriander, 1 tsp. pepper, and ½ tsp. turmeric in a medium bowl. Season with salt and toss again.Step 4Five minutes before rice is done resting, melt remaining 2 Tbsp. ghee in a large nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Add shrimp in a single layer and cook until lightly charred around the edges, about 1 minute per side. Remove from heat.Step 5Uncover rice and fluff with a fork. Add shrimp and cilantro and gently fold in until evenly distributed. Transfer pilaf to a platter and top with reserved crispy onions. Serve pilaf with lime wedges for squeezing over.How would you rate Spicy Shrimp Pilaf?Leave a ReviewTell us what you thinkReviews (12)Back to TopTriangleI love this recipe! Didn’t have any issues with the measurements or instructions and it turned out great. We’ve made it several times now and can’t wait to make it again. PelmenPortland, Oregon9/1/2021Terrible recipe.. rice/water proportions and times are not accurate at all. What a waste of time and ingredients on this.Camila 8/31/2021Delicious! A perfect date-night-in meal. Definitely agree with other reviewers that you should allow plenty of time for the onions or make them ahead. Claire7/3/2021Delicious and pretty easy, though time consuming because of one step.  It took me 50 minutes to get my onions to the right point.  They still weren't crispy, but were dark golden and sweet.  Next time, rather than use the medium pot, I'd do them in a larger pan to get more cooking area on them - or just make them in advance.  Wouldn't have been a problem but for the fact that some of them have to cook with the rice too.  This was also great as leftovers.  My young son wanted thirds!LBinTXFort Worth, TX5/25/2021I really enjoyed this! It took longer than I anticipated but that was more due to my poor planning. The sweetness of the onions mixed with the crispiness of some of the rice, yum! I can't think of any changes I'd make. Overall, this was a great dinner and I'll likely make it again. Camille Chicago, IL5/5/2021We made this and it was fabulous.  We halved the coriander.  I was surprised to see ANY reviews less than 5 stars.  Maybe the full amount of coriander is just too strong.  We shared this recipe with some friends and all will make it again.  fabulous!Northern California4/14/2021This recipe is a disaster, and I've spent a year in lockdown making other Bon Appetite recipes without problem. The rice was totally undercooked, forcing me to add more water, so I had porridge at the end.William HSeattle, WA4/13/2021This was a great recipe and extremely simple. I have a huge bag of chiles that I need to find more recipes for now!MckenzieMinnesota4/2/2021I made a couple small revisions but it was delicious and aromatic and everyone loved it. 
I added a touch of garam masala to the spice mix and threw some frozen peas in about a couple minutes before the rice was to stop cooking.   I also cooked the shrimp like cooks illustrated where you start in a cold pan and barely cook. 
It was perfect.  You can also tweak the spices and veg to make it like any other cuisine you'd like. This one is a keeper.  GK3/29/2021This was delicious.  I made it exactly as written.  My onions came out more caramelized than crispy, ( perhaps they needed to cook longer), but still added wonderful flavor.    Instead of adding the shrimp to the rice, I added the rice to the shrimp to capture more of the garlic/ginger flavor from the shrimp pan.   This was easy and pretty quick.  Definitely a keeper. Nancy Mc3/28/2021We’ve come a long way since 1971. ChrisHarrisburg, PA3/27/2021Ginger was overpowering. Coriander burnt pretty quickly when I added over the onions. My boyfriend didn’t finish his, which is a pretty good indication that this wasn’t spectacular. I don’t know that I’d make this again without some major tweaks.
